Remember what happened in Episode 4? Oh, man. I'm not even gonna spoil it for all of you newbies out there. And when Episode 7 ended, I cried, probably worse than I did at the end of "Time of the Doctor." Such quality.

Said plainly, Peter Capaldi is the best Doctor to ever take on the role. He's brilliant, mysterious, and who knew he was such a laugh riot? I know. Me neither. He makes the other Doctors bow before his sheer gravitas. And thank you, thank you, thank you, for adding Samuel Anderson as a companion. Wasn't he flipping amazing? I still don't like Clara (character), Jenna's a pretty good actress. For the longest time, I didn't like Clara and I couldn't put a finger on why. I thought it must be the transition from Amy Pond and Rory (Love them both so much!) to Clara, and if I give Clara enough time, maybe she'd grow on me. It'd been 2 and a half seasons and she didn't (7.5, 8, and 9). Something is off about her and I finally figured out what's wrong with her. The show present Clara as a bubbly character who is nice and very sympathetic about everyone around her. But the more episodes I watch, I realized something very disturbing about her character. She is able to sympathize with people, but unable to empathize with them. At all. Sympathy and empathy are very different things. She can only see things from one perspective - hers, and she expects everyone else to see and feel like her or there is something with them. She forces her will and perspective on people by means of belittling, manipulation, guilt, or moral kidnapping. In "Hide" the doctor showed her the entire cycle of the earth and she gets upset that he doesn't feel the way she does after witnessing what happened, and she gets even more upset because the first thing that popped into her mind after witnessing such splendor was accusing the doctor of seeing them all as ghosts and nothing. In "Listen" she went up to the little boy's room for no reason at all and thought it was okay. When she was under the bed in the farmhouse, she accidentally grabbed the kid's ankle by accident, told him it was a dream and go back to sleep, and instead of leaving, she decided to pet his head and whispers into his ear as if something from under the bed grabbing your ankle in the middle of the night wasn't scary enough. Again, because from her point of view, she was comforting him, without considering the fact that her actions were terrifying him. "In the forest of the night" she made the decision that none of the kids will get to be saved by the Tardis because they will want their parents, will always want their parents so they should stay on earth and die with their parents (without asking anyone if they want to be saved or stay and die). In "Dark Waters", Her beloved boyfriend got into a car accident and passed away, an old lady said it was a terrible thing, she said "It wasn't terrible. It's boring. It was ordinary." Then said "But I am owed...better. I am owed." I understand shock and grief, but her boyfriend just die and she said it was too boring a death and that SHE is owed. Not Danny is owed. Another instant where her lack of empathy kick in was when she convinced a man to risk his life to get her cellphone back, caring very little about his safety. The more episodes I watch, clues are popping up all over the place point to companion Clara being a psychopath. And what is the one thing that a psychopath lacks? Empathy. Another thing that's annoying about Clara is that she tries too hard to become the doctor. Not sure why the writer makes this trait so pronounce in Clara. It would be interesting to find out one day.

Season 8 has the best stand-alone episodes in DW with Mummy on the Orient Express, Flatline, Listen. Both Capaldi and Coleman have the most challenging episodes to act out in DW and they do it incredibly well. The fun romps like Robots and Time Heist and Deep Breath are watchable multiple times. The Danny Pink arc may not be appealing to many viewers but is saved by the acting of Capaldi and Coleman and offer some incredible dramatic moments. The season also takes a sharp turn in distinguishing itself from the previous New Who eras and making itself the most unique season. Capaldi as the acerbic 12th Doctor but with an incredible heart who wears his alienness (and vulnerability) on his sleeve is the polar opposite of 11. Overall, most of the episodes have excellent writing, acting, and direction. Standout season in all ways.

I would recommend at least watching series eight part one before this, but to really get into it try a few episodes from all seven previous "new" series and maybe a few bits from the older (1960's to 1980's) show of the same name.

Coming off of my favorite Doctor ever in Matt Smith, Peter Capaldi and, it would soon become apparent, the writers had a hard act to follow. The Twelfth Doctor lost all the fun that Smith and Tennant had. To fill the void they up the anger and mean spiritedness that the previous Doctors had sometimes.

The initial episodes weren't just darker but they really slowed the pace of the show down. To make matters worse, they minimized the use of background music. Depending on the scene, this further darkened the mood or took away something that would've added to the mood.

I thought having Jenna Coleman remain on would smooth the transition but the writers chose to alter her character and her relationship with the Doctor. Again, taking away the fun and adding conflict, in-fighting and melodrama in it's place. It also seems at times like their past history is forgotten for the sake of melodrama. As an example, during the "Mummy on the Orient Express" episode, at the beginning, the Doctor comments on Clara's smile in a way that's just a downer and makes him completely unlikeable. Then he repeats the comment and they linger on it. I don't see the point of it.

I guess the positives are that Jenna Coleman gives some great performances even if some of the scenes don't ring true emotionally. The end of the season felt the most Doctor-y both in that it felt more fun but also, unfortunately, in how silly it got.

As Dr. Who settles into yet another incarnation in the form of Peter Capaldi, it is a little jarring to me as it must be to many fans.  The Doctor is having a hard time of it, too, as his prodigious memory is being filtered through another Senior Personality.  It has been a long time since he was "old" in appearance and although he has always been wise and venerable, his recent companions could join in with someone who at least appears to be a peer.  It is particularly hard for Clara, the Savior of the Doctor many times throughout history.  She is in a complicated relationship with a contemporary who is unaware of his past relationships with Clara.  He is totally accepting of everything that Clara tells him, but he demands honesty of her.  She is afraid of losing him but he tells her to "Fear a little bit less. Trust a little bit more."  I haven't yet finished watching this season because I'm afraid of what to do when it ends.  I'm trying to trust that there will be even more to come.

Unlikely as it sounds, the great show runner and writer Stephen Moffat seems to have not been informed that he is writing for a different lead actor. Season 8 is full of dialogue that would've been perfect coming out of Matt Smith's mouth. Capaldi, however, seems to still be playing Malcolm Tucker, although the swearing is replaced with neutron-flow reversing technobabble. They eventually find the right way to present Twelve, but it doesn't happen until season 9. The highlights of season 8 are few and dim: "Listen" had huge potential, but instead focused on establishing a secondary character's backstory (who ends up dying anyway) and "Time Heist" was a fun, energetic caper but had a few Deus-Ex-Machina moments that were difficult to believe. Overall, the season was an exercise in expensive mistakes, and it's hard to believe the show runners let it get this bad before righting the ship again (in spectacular fashion) in season 9. Skip the Robin Hood episode, and go straight to "Dark Water" and "Death In Heaven". Then you can watch season 9 with renewed appreciation for what Doctor Who really is about.

3 stars for anything else is average, for Doctor Who, it's "rubbish". First off, I really enjoyed Capaldi as The Doctor. He is one of the best, if not THE best aspects of series 8. The problems with series 8 begin with The Doctor's companion, Clara Oswald. It's not Jenna Coleman's fault though, she does a good job with what she's given. The issue is that she (and all the minor characters in the Steven Moffat Era for that matter) is given WAY too much to do. The Doctor often times takes a back seat in his own show, sometimes overlooking simple solutions to problems so that Clara can swoop in and save the day. This wouldn't be as much of a problem if Clara was a well written, three dimensional character but sadly, she's not. As the viewer, you never really connect with Clara or her boyfriend Danny Pink. Moffat's weaknesses as a show runner are no more apparent than with the characters he creates. Characters that always seem to fall into two distinct categories: Bland or Mary Sue. Madame Vastra? Mary Sue, Danny Pink? Bland, River Song? Mary Sue.
And so on....
At times, Moffat almost seems to be self-gratifying in the writing of these characters and won't stop shoving them down your throat until you think they're as amazing as he believes. "Isn't Madame Vastra awesome? She's a Lizard woman living in Victorian London who eats criminals and solves crimes! Isn't she so unique and amazing?! Wow! Did you see that? She's so cool isn't she?" I am constantly pulled out of the show by how hard it's trying to convince me how "great" it is now. What made the RTD Era so great were characters that you became emotionally invested in. And I found myself no more aware of this then when a character who appeared throughout the season, met a tragic end in the finale. In what should have been a gut-wrenching moment, I was actually angry with the show because I just didn't care about this character. I wanted to care, but I just didn't. I wanted to ball my eyes out, I wanted to have that same feeling I had when Rose's father sacrificed himself for her, or when Donna met her fate, or Rose got trapped in an alternate dimension or when "he" knocked four times... But nothing. Any sadness I did manage to feel was for my own lack of compassion for these characters.

So 3 stars because the stories are still good, I just don't care about the characters in them.

Anytime a new Doctor regenerates, there is always an adjustment period, which should not be considered when rating the season, because it is a real part of this shows long history.
I began watching Doctor Who in 2005, with C. Eccleston as the Doctor - so my experience is limited to a three Doctors who were in a similar age range, and were energetic, vibrant and passionate.  This new Doctor is considerably older, and required a much bigger adjustment.  The first episode did a great job of having the current Companion, Clara, go through the same adjustment with the audience.  She didn't like it at first, and had trouble expressing why.  The reality is that this Doctor is not a young man with relationship potential.  He's more of a father-figure, and this takes quite some getting used to (on both sides of the TV Screen)
This new Doctor/Companion relationship develops and grows for both Clara and the audience, with some interesting storylines that contain lots of foreshadowing and historical references, as usual.  A new male character is introduced with relationship-potential for Clara, and the historically common storyline of keeping the Doctor a secret.  This all builds to an intriguing and heart-wrenching ending to the season.

I got to borrow Doctor Who Season 8 from my local library and just finished watching the whole thing.  It took me an episode or two to get used to Peter Capaldi as the new Doctor, but he DID win me over. I began to really like Mr. Capaldi as the new, older, wiser, more reflective and grumpier Doctor.

What didn't 'win me over' was the mounting annoyance of Clara (Jenna Coleman). Clara was okay with Matt Smith in Season 7 as 'Souffl Girl' and as the 'Impossible Girl'  but somehow her smarmy, manipulative, even disrespectful comments to the older, wiser (and grumpier) Doctor only came across as her being an overbearing, ungrateful, 'itch-bay'.

The writers could have made their relationship so much classier if they'd created a fatherly/grandfatherly - daughter/granddaughter relationship instead of Clara continually thinking she knew more than, or was smarter than, the Doctor.  It got to the point where I was hoping the Doctor would find a new companion, the sooner the better.

I loved all of the Doctor's previous companions (Rose, Martha, Amy, even Donna) but somehow, Clara didn't fit well with the new Doctor.  So many times in Season 8, Clara threatened the Doctor with different manipulative tricks  all of which I kept hoping were her last episode. But no. Clara kept popping back up and boring us to death.

One 'new' thing about Season 8, which I hadn't experienced before in any other Doctor Who season, was this impatient urge for whatever episode I was watching at the time to end  soon  hoping the next one would be better. But alas, not to be. The 'Mistress' episodes were the worst and I blame Coleman's poor acting and the horrible casting choice for 'The Mistress'.

Most villains in the Doctor Who series you just 'love to hate'  but 'The Mistress' (Michelle Gomez) was just too irritating to bother with. Not sure how Ms. Gomez convinced anyone to give her the part but she just plain STUNK!  Gawd! Even worse than Coleman, if that's possible.

However, on a brighter note, I thought Samuel Anderson (Danny Pink) was great  unfortunately, it doesn't look like he's gonna be in Season 9. Won't give away anything, but Mr. Anderson, along with Peter Capaldi, made Season 8 watchable.

I have bought, from Amazon, ALL the previous seven seasons of Doctor Who  from Christopher Eccleston (Season 1) through David Tennant (Seasons 2-4) and Matt Smith (Seasons 5-7) and all of the Specials.  Needless to say, I won't be paying money to buy Season 8. I can only hope Season 9 will be better.

Edit: I just had the pleasure of watching "The Last Christmas" and it was fantastic. Even Clara redeemed herself, so maybe the writers are getting the 'feel' for this new Doctor and his companion a bit better. Anyway, worth a look-see.

Of all the seasons of Doctor Who which I have watched so far (up to this season of New Who), this is the most consistently-delivering season, with consistently fantastic episodes. They're told with a tight and concise style and hold attention very effectively; visually creative and beautifully and audaciously shot.
The stories are some of the best I've ever seen on Doctor Who: "Listen" and "Deep Breath" are in the running with "Dalek" and "The Empty Child/The Doctor Dances" for my favorite Doctor Who stories of all time. They're very well told, with a very real sense of menace, akin to "Blink," "Silence in the Library/Forest of the Dead," and "Midnight." In fact, "Listen" was the most terrifying Doctor Who episode I have ever seen, in my opinion, but I couldn't stop watching.
On the other hand, I don't know if this season would make good family-friendly viewing material. I wouldn't recommend it for young children, certainly; parts of it are too dark and too scary, and I doubt that very young children would appreciate the plot twists fully.
I'm sure, from all the criticisms I've seen of Clara, that this season won't be everyone's cup of tea, however. But for myself, I have to rate this season five stars.
